questions.text: A lesion in the Brodmann area 22 will cause:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Brodmann area 22 corresponds to Wernicke's area, located in the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere (usually left). A lesion in this area causes Wernicke's aphasia, also known as receptive aphasia, characterised by impaired comprehension and fluent but meaningless speech (word salad).


Explanation for other options:

Expressive aphasia (Option A): Expressive aphasia (Broca's aphasia) results from a lesion in Brodmann area 44 & 45 (Broca's area), causing non-fluent speech with intact comprehension.

Poor repetition of language (Option C): This is characteristic of conduction aphasia, which occurs due to damage in the arcuate fasciculus, disrupting communication between Wernicke's and Broca's areas.

Poor naming (Option D): While naming impairment can occur, it is not specific to Wernicke's aphasia; anomic aphasia primarily affects naming ability.

Reference:

  1. Aphasia
  2. Conduction Aphasia

questions.text: A patient presents with faecal discharge emerging from the umbilicus. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Faecal discharge from the umbilicus suggests a persistent connection between the intestine and the umbilicus.
  • Meckel’s diverticulum with a fistula (a congenital remnant of the vitellointestinal duct) can cause faecal umbilical discharge.

questions.text: Match the receptors with their correct function:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Each mechanoreceptor has a distinct function based on its structure and location in the skin.

questions.text: Injury to which cranial nerve causes an absent gag reflex?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Damage to either CN IX or CN X can lead to an absent gag reflex, causing difficulty in swallowing (dysphagia) and an increased risk of aspiration.

The gag reflex (pharyngeal reflex) involves both the afferent and efferent limbs controlled by cranial nerves:

Cranial Nerves and Reflexes

Cranial nerves (CN) play a crucial role in reflexes by acting as afferent (sensory) or efferent (motor) pathways. Below is a summary of important cranial nerve-mediated reflexes:


Explanation for other options:

Cranial nerves X and VII (Option B): CN VII (Facial nerve) is involved in facial expression, not the gag reflex.

Cranial nerves VII and V (Option C): CN V (Trigeminal nerve) is responsible for facial sensation and mastication, not the gag reflex.

Cranial nerves V and IX (Option D): CN V is not involved in the motor response of the gag reflex.

questions.text: Implantation occurs on which day post-fertilisation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Implantation begins around Day 5 post-fertilisation when the blastocyst reaches the uterus and starts attaching to the endometrial lining. The process continues over the next few days, with full implantation completed by Day 9-10.


Reference:

  1. First week of development

questions.text: A patient presenting with sciatica exhibits tenderness in the hamstring muscles. Which of the following nerves innervates a hybrid muscle that remains unaffected in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is the Obturator nerve, as it supplies the adductor part of the hybrid muscles and remains unaffected in this condition.

  • Sciatica involves the sciatic nerve (L4-S3), which supplies the hamstrings (except for the short head of biceps femoris).
  • The adductor magnus is a hybrid muscle with dual innervation:
    • Adductor part → Obturator nerve (L2-L4)
    • Hamstring part → Tibial nerve (L4-S3)
  • Since the tibial nerve is affected in sciatica, the hamstring part of the adductor magnus is involved, but the adductor part (supplied by the obturator nerve) is spared.

Explanation for other options:

Femoral nerve (Option A): Incorrect because it supplies the rectus femoris, which is not relevant to sciatica.

Common peroneal nerve (Option B): Incorrect because it supplies the short head of biceps femoris, which can be affected in sciatica.

Tibial nerve (Option D) Incorrect because it is part of the sciatic nerve, meaning it is affected in this patient.

questions.text: A patient complains of pain radiating down the posterior thigh and leg following a heavy lifting episode. Which spinal nerve root is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The S1 nerve root is most commonly associated with pain radiating down the posterior leg, including the hamstring and calf muscles.

  • The patient is presenting with pain in the back of the thigh and leg after lifting heavy weights, which is consistent with sciatica-like pain.
  • The S1 root is responsible for innervating the muscles of the posterior thigh and the calf, and it is often affected in cases of sciatica, particularly after heavy lifting or straining.

Explanation for other options:

L4 (Option A): Because L4 is more likely to cause pain radiating to the anterior thigh and knee, rather than the posterior thigh and leg.

L5 (Option B) Because L5 involvement typically causes pain that radiates to the lateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum of the foot.

S2 (Option D): While S2 may be involved in some cases of sciatica, S1 is more commonly associated with posterior leg pain.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms plays a key role in preventing polyspermy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cortical reaction: After the sperm enters the egg, cortical granules in the egg release enzymes that modify the zona pellucida, preventing further sperm from binding and entering the egg, thus preventing polyspermy.

Explanation for other options:

Acrosome reaction (Option A): It helps the sperm penetrate the egg, not prevent polyspermy.

Zona reaction (Option C): Although it helps block other sperm after one has entered, the cortical reaction is the main process preventing polyspermy.

Capacitation (Option D): It enables sperm to fertilise the egg but does not directly prevent polyspermy.

questions.text: A professional singer reports difficulty producing high-pitched notes. Examination reveals bowing of the right vocal cord. Which of the following muscles is most likely impaired?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The cricothyroid muscle is responsible for tensioning and elongating the vocal cords, which helps in adjusting pitch. Damage to this muscle can result in difficulty in achieving higher pitches, leading to symptoms like hoarseness or difficulty singing at high pitches.

Explanation for other options:

Posterior cricoarytenoid (Option A): This muscle abducts (opens) the vocal cords, which is not related to high-pitch singing or vocal cord bowing.

Lateral cricoarytenoid (Option B): It adducts (closes) the vocal cords, and it does not affect pitch in the same way as the cricothyroid muscle.

Thyroarytenoid (Option D): It is involved in relaxing the vocal cords, which lowers the pitch and does not contribute to high-pitch singing.

questions.text: Paralysis of which muscle causes ptosis in Horner's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ptosis in Horner's syndrome is primarily due to the paralysis of the superior tarsal muscle (also known as Müller's muscle).

  • This muscle is responsible for maintaining the eyelid position and lifting the upper eyelid slightly.
  • In Horner's syndrome, the sympathetic innervation to the superior tarsal muscle is disrupted, resulting in ptosis (drooping of the eyelid).

Explanation for other options:

Orbitalis (Option B): The orbitalis muscle is not involved in ptosis. It helps in closing the eyelids but does not contribute to the sympathetic control of the eyelid.

Orbicularis oculi (Option C): This muscle is responsible for closing the eyelid, but ptosis in Horner's syndrome is caused by a sympathetic defect affecting the superior tarsal muscle, not the orbicularis oculi.

Sphincter pupillae (Option D): The sphincter pupillae muscle is responsible for pupil constriction (miosis) under parasympathetic control, not related to ptosis in Horner's syndrome.

choices.text: A- Eccrine sweat gland, B- Arrector pilorum, C- Sebaceous gland, D- Apocrine gland
A- Arrector pilorum, B- Eccrine sweat gland, C- Sebaceous gland, D- Apocrine gland

A- Sebaceous gland, B- Apocrine gland, C- Eccrine sweat gland, D- Arrector pilorum

questions.text: Identify the markers in the given slide:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

These markers on the provided slide match the following structures:

  • A: Eccrine sweat glands: Found all over the skin, these play a role in thermoregulation.
  • B: Arrector pili: Tiny muscles that contract to make hair stand upright and are connected to hair follicles.
  • C: Sebaceous gland: Sebum-secreting glands that coat and lubricate skin and hair.
  • D: Apocrine gland: Located in the groin and axilla, these glands secrete thicker sweat, which adds to body odour.

Histology of Glands

  • Glands are specialised structures in the body that produce and secrete substances such as hormones, enzymes, or other fluids.
  • Histologically, they can be classified based on their secretion type, structure, and function. Here's an overview of the different types of glands:

choices.text: A- Superior vena cava, B- Ascending aorta, C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Descending aorta
A- Ascending aorta, B- Descending aorta, C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Superior vena cava
A- Ascending aorta, B- Superior vena cava, C- Descending aorta, D- Pulmonary trunk
A- Ascending aorta, B- Superior Vena Cava, C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Descending aorta

questions.text: Identify the labelling correctly:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A - Superior Vena Cava: The superior vena cava is usually located on the right side of the image, returning deoxygenated blood from the upper body to the right atrium of the heart.

B - Ascending Aorta: The ascending aorta originates from the left ventricle and is positioned just slightly to the left of the superior vena cava.

C - Pulmonary Trunk: The pulmonary trunk is located just beneath the ascending aorta and carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs.

D - Descending Aorta: The descending aorta is located posteriorly, descending downward after arching around the left side of the heart.

questions.text: Identify the nerve marked in the given picture.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The medial pectoral nerve innervates the pectoralis minor and pectoralis major muscles. It originates from the medial cord of the brachial plexus and courses through the axilla to supply these muscles, making it the correct answer in this context.

Explanation for other options:

Lateral pectoral nerve (Option B): This nerve also innervates the pectoralis major muscle but originates from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus, running in a slightly different pathway compared to the medial pectoral nerve.

Long thoracic nerve (Option C): This nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle, which is located along the lateral chest wall. It doesn't fit with the labelling in the image if it's marking the pectoral muscles.

Thoracodorsal nerve (Option D): This nerve innervates the latissimus dorsi muscle, located on the back and not in the region of the pectoral muscles.

Reference:

  1. Medscape - When is a modified radical mastectomy indicated

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented with a lesion as shown below. This would cause what kind of field abnormality?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bitemporal hemianopia occurs due to a lesion at the optic chiasm, where nasal fibres from both eyes cross. Since these fibres are responsible for the temporal visual fields, their damage leads to loss of vision in the outer halves of both visual fields.

  • Common causes: Pituitary adenoma, craniopharyngioma, or meningioma compressing the optic chiasm.

Explanation for other options:

Homonymous hemianopia (Option A): This results from a lesion posterior to the optic chiasm (e.g., in the optic tract, lateral geniculate body, or occipital lobe).

Complete blindness (Option C): Total blindness occurs due to a lesion before the optic chiasm affecting the optic nerve of one eye.

Single vision field loss (Option D): This occurs with a lesion affecting only one optic nerve, not the chiasm.

questions.text: Which artery lies in front of the Achilles and behind the medial malleolus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The posterior tibial artery passes behind the medial malleolus and runs in front of the Achilles tendon, within the tarsal tunnel. It provides blood supply to the posterior compartment of the leg and the plantar surface of the foot.


Explanation for other options:

Peroneal artery (Option B): It runs along the lateral compartment of the leg and does not pass behind the medial malleolus.

Anterior tibial artery (Option C): It passes anteriorly through the interosseous membrane and does not course behind the medial malleolus.

Dorsalis pedis artery (Option D): It is a continuation of the anterior tibial artery and is located on the dorsum of the foot.

choices.text: Loss of sensation in the mucosa of the nasopharynx
Loss of sensation in the maxillary area of the face
Loss of sensation in the jaw area
Loss of sensation in the scalp and nose

questions.text: On lesion of the nerve passing through the red arrow-marked region. What will be the clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The red arrow in the given image likely marks the supraorbital foramen, through which the supraorbital nerve (a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve, CN V1) passes. Lesioning this nerve would cause sensory loss in the scalp, forehead, and upper nose region.

Explanation for other options:

Loss of sensation in the mucosa of the nasopharynx (Option A): Incorrect because this is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), not the supraorbital nerve.

Loss of sensation in the maxillary area of the face (Option B). Incorrect because the maxillary division (V2), passing through the foramen rotundum, supplies this region.

Loss of sensation in the jaw area (Option C): Incorrect because the mandibular division (V3), not the supraorbital nerve, supplies sensation to the jaw.
